verses.text: But the Israelites were unfaithful concerning the things set apart for destruction. Achan son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah, of the tribe of Judah, took some of the devoted things. So the LORD’s anger burned against the Israelites.
verses.comment: Achan's act is seen not just as an individual sin but as affecting the whole community. In Scripture, the sin of one often has corporate consequences (see Rom. 5:12).

verses.text: Joshua sent men from Jericho to Ai, which is near Beth-aven, east of Bethel, and said to them, 'Go up and spy out the land.' So the men went up and spied out Ai.
verses.comment: Like the earlier sending of spies to Jericho, Joshua continues Israel's pattern of investigating before battle. Ai means 'ruin'; its significance grows due to what follows.

verses.text: They returned to Joshua and said to him, 'Do not have all the people go up; let about two or three thousand men go up and attack Ai. Do not make all the people toil there, for they are few.'
verses.comment: The spies underestimate Ai, possibly due to overconfidence after Jericho's fall. Human calculation stands in contrast to dependence on God.

verses.text: So about three thousand men went up there from the people, but they fled before the men of Ai.
verses.comment: Despite superior numbers, Israel's defeat highlights that victory is not by human strength alone, but by God's favor (see Ps. 127:1).

verses.text: The men of Ai struck down about thirty-six of them, and chased them from before the gate as far as Shebarim and struck them down on the descent. The hearts of the people melted and became like water.
verses.comment: The defeat reverses earlier reports of Canaanites’ hearts melting. Now Israel experiences fear because of their disobedience.

verses.text: Then Joshua tore his clothes and fell to the ground with his face to the earth before the Ark of the LORD until evening, both he and the elders of Israel; and they put dust on their heads.
verses.comment: Tearing garments and putting dust on the head symbolize mourning and repentance. Joshua turns to prayer before the Ark, the visible sign of God's presence among His people.

verses.text: Joshua said, 'Alas, Lord GOD, why have you brought this people across the Jordan at all, to give us into the hand of the Amorites, to destroy us? If only we had been content to dwell beyond the Jordan!'
verses.comment: This echoes the complaints of Israel in Moses’ time—questioning God's motives in hardships, showing human weakness in faith. Yet, God uses such prayers to lead His people toward trust and deeper surrender.

verses.text: O Lord, what can I say, now that Israel has turned their backs before their enemies?
verses.comment: Joshua’s question signifies perplexity and the humility to seek God’s wisdom above his own.

verses.text: 'For the Canaanites and all the inhabitants of the land will hear of it, and will surround us and cut off our name from the earth. What then will you do for your great name?'
verses.comment: Joshua appeals to God’s own reputation, reflecting how Moses prayed (Exod. 32:12). God’s covenant people exist ultimately to glorify His name.

verses.text: The LORD said to Joshua, 'Get up! Why have you fallen on your face?'
verses.comment: God calls Joshua from lamentation to action, showing that while prayer is essential, obedience to divine instruction must follow.

verses.text: 'Israel has sinned; they have also transgressed my covenant which I commanded them. They have even taken some of the things devoted to destruction, they have stolen, deceived, and put them among their own things.'
verses.comment: God lays responsibility on all Israel. The spiritual principle that the sin of one affects all (see 1 Cor. 12:26) is stressed. Spiritual solidarity among the people of God foreshadows the spiritual union found in the Body of Christ.

verses.text: 'Therefore the people of Israel cannot stand before their enemies. They turn their backs before their enemies, because they have become devoted to destruction. I will not be with you any more unless you destroy the devoted things from among you.'
verses.comment: God’s presence is conditional on obedience. This serves as a serious call to repentance and purity among God’s people—made complete later in the new covenant with Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: 'Get up! Consecrate the people and say, “Consecrate yourselves for tomorrow; for thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, ‘There are devoted things in your midst, O Israel. You cannot stand before your enemies until you remove the devoted things from among you.’”'
verses.comment: Consecration is an act of preparation and purification, necessary for experiencing God’s presence. This prefigures later practices of confession and penance before receiving the new covenant’s fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: 'In the morning you shall be brought near by your tribes. The tribe that the LORD takes by lot shall come near by clans, and the clan that the LORD takes shall come near by households, and the household that the LORD takes shall come near man by man.'
verses.comment: God uses a sacred lot to reveal the guilty party, reflecting a divinely ordained system for establishing order and accountability among His people.

verses.text: 'And the one who is taken with the devoted things shall be burned with fire, he and all that he has, because he has transgressed the covenant of the LORD and has done a disgraceful thing in Israel.'
verses.comment: The punishment is severe, underscoring the gravity of communal holiness. The idea of being ‘devoted’ to destruction (herem) means absolute surrender to God’s justice and rule.

verses.text: So Joshua rose early in the morning and brought Israel near tribe by tribe, and the tribe of Judah was taken.
verses.comment: Judah is highlighted, the tribe from which both King David and, ultimately, Christ would descend (see Matt. 1:2-3). This foreshadows how Christ bears the sin of His people.

verses.text: He brought near the clans of Judah, and the clan of the Zerahites was taken. Then he brought near the clan of the Zerahites man by man, and Zabdi was taken.
verses.comment: Tracing the guilt down line by line illustrates both divine omniscience and the fulfillment of God’s appointed means of order in the community.

verses.text: He brought near his household man by man, and Achan, son of Carmi, son of Zabdi, son of Zerah, from the tribe of Judah, was taken.
verses.comment: God’s process is patient but exact; nothing can be hidden from the Lord (see Heb. 4:13).

verses.text: Then Joshua said to Achan, 'My son, give glory to the LORD, the God of Israel, and give him praise. Tell me what you have done; do not hide it from me.'
verses.comment: Confession is urged as a means of giving glory to God. The act of owning one’s sin before God is vital throughout Scripture and in ongoing Christian discipline.

verses.text: Achan answered Joshua, 'Truly I have sinned against the LORD, the God of Israel, and this is what I did:'
verses.comment: Achan’s confession echoes David’s later confession in Psalm 51 and shows the principle of private and public admission of guilt within God’s people.

verses.text: 'When I saw among the spoil a beautiful cloak from Shinar, two hundred shekels of silver, and a bar of gold weighing fifty shekels, I took them. And, see, they are hidden in the ground inside my tent, with the silver under it.'
verses.comment: Achan’s progression—seeing, coveting, taking—mirrors Eve’s sin in Eden. The pattern of temptation and hiding marks all humanity's fallen nature.

verses.text: So Joshua sent messengers, and they ran to the tent, and there it was, hidden in his tent, with the silver underneath.
verses.comment: Verification is made publicly, underscoring the need for truth and accountability among the people.

verses.text: They took them out of the tent and brought them to Joshua and to all the people of Israel, and they laid them down before the LORD.
verses.comment: Bringing the items before the Lord stresses the seriousness of sin and the communal responsibility for holiness.

verses.text: Then Joshua and all Israel with him took Achan son of Zerah, the silver, the cloak, the bar of gold, his sons, his daughters, his oxen, his donkeys, his sheep, his tent, and all that he had. They brought them up to the Valley of Achor.
verses.comment: The Valley of Achor becomes a lasting sign of trouble and judgment, yet later is spoken of as a place of hope. All that pertained to Achan is included, illustrating the depth of consequences sin brings into families and communities.

verses.text: Joshua said, 'Why have you brought trouble upon us? The LORD will bring trouble upon you this day.' And all Israel stoned him with stones, and they burned them with fire and stoned them with stones.
verses.comment: The severe penalty underlines the costliness of sin against God’s holiness, pointing toward the need for a final, sufficient atonement—which comes through Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: They raised over him a great heap of stones that remains to this day. Then the LORD turned from his burning anger. Therefore the name of that place has been called the Valley of Achor to this day.
verses.comment: The mound of stones serves as a memorial and warning. The Lord’s anger is turned aside by full obedience, prefiguring the atonement for sin made perfect in the new covenant by Christ, who is both Priest and Victim.
